it practices inverted methods,
holds the inverted path.
The great adept, having refined himself thoroughly,
remains unmoved in body and mind,
the soul and spirit subdued,
desire not intruding,
the essence and qi full—
like a wealthy household,
where gold and jade abound everywhere.
When the first *yáng* stirs,
the primordial true lead approaches,
and yet my body’s essence and qi remain still.
I simply take a drop of true mercury nearby in the lower kidney
to greet it—
this is the *short advance* of the fore-stage.

Once the true lead has crossed the Magpie Bridge,
mercury and lead merge,
then follow the lead as it ascends—
the three revolving wheels pass through the double pass,
the spinal column, and the *niwan*,
traversing the Nine Palaces,
entering the twin eyes,
descending the Golden Bridge,
passing the Red Tower,
entering the Vermilion Palace,
and returning to the Yellow Court’s divine chamber—
this is the *long retreat* of the later stage."*

Master Shangyang said:
*"The *niwan* says:
*'If my practice lasts one year,
the six pulses will cease, and the breath returns to the root.'*
Laozi says:
*'Devote the breath to supreme softness,
and you may be like an infant.'*
Both speak of nourishment.

Nourishment means
weakening the limbs,
dulling the senses—
all day like a fool, yet never straying,
never to be separated for an instant.
Like a hen brooding her eggs,
the warm breath must never cease,
and the work of extraction and addition will naturally appear.

Extraction and addition mean:
after the lead restrains the mercury,
gradually move the fire each day,
slowly adding mercury—
as mercury increases, lead decreases,
until the lead is exhausted,
the mercury dries,
and becomes cinnabar—
the pure *yang* essence of the Golden Elixir.

At this point, the breath transforms into seed—
this is the infant,
this is the *yang* spirit."*

The *Emerald Emptiness Chapter* says:
*"At first, the spinal pass opens,

now stir the heart’s source!

yet who separates the metal and wood?

governing all phenomena, the heart holds sway.

husband and wife in perfect harmony.
The jade cauldron simmers with elixir,
the golden furnace blazes with fire.

shaking heaven and earth.
A hundred meridians surge,
the three passes pierce through.

The dark pearl takes form,
the Supreme Unity embraces the True.
The *dantian* wind stirs,
the Vermilion Palace glows with moonlight,
the cinnabar field warms with mist,
the *guhai* sea ripples clear.

Refining the Returning Elixir—
easy as turning one’s palm.
Henceforth, the Celestial Pass is in hand,
the Earthly Axis moves with the heart,
and one may wield the *lingqi* banner by day,
record divine herbs by night.

Warming the Sacred Embryo,
forming the Red Child.

Zhuangzi said:
*"All comes down to this single effort—
eternal boundless joy preserved."*

This is the foundation of the Dao,
the root of virtue,
the lineage of Dragon and Tiger,
the origin of lead and mercury.
One fire gathered,
eight waters converging—
the gate where ten thousand spirits assemble,
the source of the Golden Elixir’s marvels,
the pivotal moment of returning to the root and reclaiming life.

desire need not be abandoned—
the mind stilled of its own accord,
the spirit clarified without effort.
No thought arises,
ten thousand illusions dissolve,
the body rides the *fuxiao* winds,

the Dao’s breeze and moon’s purity—

the green waters and blue mountains—
fully disclosing the essence of Dragon and Tiger.

*The Sea Guest’s Treatise* says:

naturally the sacred body is perfected,
the ten-month embryo complete,

the source of all transformation and generation.

Xiao Zixu said:

*The Heavenly Immortal’s True Principles* say:

*'From now on, only blow the windless flute,
from today, strike the stringless zither.'*"

*"The Great Microcosmic Orbit—
like the sun completing one full revolution.

all to complete the ten-month celestial orbit.

some in eight, nine, or ten.

some take months beyond ten, even countless,

in the eighth, ninth, or tenth month,

some see wonders, some hear marvels,

some trustworthy or deceptive matters,

refining qi and transforming spirit with pure intent,
until even breathing ceases and demons retreat."*

*The Heavenly Immortal’s True Principles* say:
*"If a stray thought arises within,
quickly summon right mindfulness—
the stray thought vanishes.

quickly summon right mindfulness—
do not engage, and the demon retreats.
The *Forty-Nine Chapter Scripture* says:
*'Do not contend with the hemp demon—
those who come will return on their own.'*
Ge Ding Lingyang said:
*'In stillness, deepening the practice,
one may see sages, Buddhas, ghosts, spirits,
palaces, radiance—
do not let the heart cling or reject.'*
Yu Yuwu said:
*'Let a thousand transformations unfold—
the mind unmoved, all evils retreat.'*"

*The Heavenly Immortal’s True Principles* say:
*"Once breathing is truly absent,
qi returns to pure spirit—
no longer is there qi or breath.
If breath remains, though seemingly without leakage,
it is not true cessation.
If breathing is only partially still,
the spirit follows—
only partially still, not fully.
Now is the time for meticulous practice,
entering Great Stillness and pure spirit.
If there is any interruption or separation,
it is like fleeing the Elixir—
one must reach the point of no qi before completion.
This is the second gate’s principle of Returning to One,
restoring the state of primordial union before birth.
A child’s ten months—form complete, life begins.
A spirit-embryo’s ten months—spirit complete, transcendence is achieved.
This is the natural order.
Master Qiu said:
*'If breath is ever unstable by a hair,
life is not yet secured.'*"

*The Heavenly Immortal’s True Principles* say:
*"The Great Microcosmic Orbit’s fire is beyond divination—
not forced, yet not idle,
warmly continuous,
neither clinging to presence nor absence,
initially seeming neither here nor there,
ultimately returning to Great Stillness."*

*The Great Communion Scripture* says:
*"The Dao has no form—
thus within, it is not confined by existence.
True nature is without action—
thus without, the heart is not lost."*

*The Supreme Lord’s Daily Scripture* says:
*"Spirit is the child of qi,
qi is the mother of spirit—
like a hen brooding an egg,
nurturing spirit and preserving qi,
how could they ever separate?
Wonderful! Wonderful!"*

*The Dragon and Tiger Scripture* says:
*"The most subtle essence lies in first having, then forgetting."*

*The Essentials of Nature and Life* say:
*"When the embryo-breath is congealed and refined,
inhalation gathers without accumulation,
exhalation disperses without scattering—
the body’s form becomes void and empty,
merging indistinctly into Stillness."*

Master Qiu Changchun said:
*"A single thought not straying from the mind’s center—this is True Void.
This is the fire of embryo-nurturing,
the True Fire."*

Lu Hongxian said:
*"With each breath, the mind fades into thoughtlessness,
half-awake, faintly sensing the body’s buoyancy."*

Zhang Suqiong said:
*"When refining reaches the point where form and spirit merge in obscurity,
one then knows that color and appearance are True Void."*

*The Hundred-Phrase Chapter* says:
*"Herein lies true faith—
when faith arrives, you shall be astonished.
A single point like a cinnabar orange,
must be met with mercury’s embrace—
no tools or instruments are needed,
for the method inverts heaven and earth."*

Lu Ziyou said:
*"To attain the One is to hold life within oneself—
a body beyond the body,
equal in years to Heaven."*

Shangyangzi said:
*"The Golden Elixir is the primordial *qi* of yin and yang,
the very origin of the Supreme Ultimate,
the root of Heaven and Earth."*

Zhang Ziyang said:
*"All comes down to this single moment’s practice—
eternally preserving boundless ease and joy."*

Shangyangzi said:
*"The Golden Elixir comes from without,
swallowed into the abdomen.
The Returned Elixir—only half a moment—
seizes the creative power of Heaven and Earth,
seizes the creative power of the Supreme Ultimate before division,
seizes the creative power of Heaven and Earth in their copulation,
seizes the creative power of yin and yang’s unfathomable interplay,
seizes the creative power of water and fire’s completion,
seizes the creative power of the Five Phases’ conquests,
seizes the creative power of all things’ genesis—
all gathered in an instant.
How could one not tremble with reverence?"*

Xue Zixian said:
*"The Yang Elixir comes from without,
refining one’s own yin mercury."*

Mei Zhixian said:
*"The yin mud pellet—
a single breath cycles through,
descending through the earthly gate,
ascending to meet the heavenly pass."*

*The Transmission of the Dao Collection* says:
*"When spirit gathers, demons multiply.
Moving true fire to burn the body,
the Three Corpses vanish,
the medicine reaches the sea’s exhaustion—
drawing the River Vehicle’s essence to bathe,
one enters water without ripples.
These are the operations of the River Vehicle."*

*The Transmission of the Dao Collection* says:
*"When the Dragon and Tiger unite and transform into yellow sprouts,
this is the Small River Vehicle.
When the arm’s gold flies and enters the mud pellet,
extracting lead to add mercury to form the great medicine,
this is the Great River Vehicle."*

*The Transmission of the Dao Collection* says:
*"Water and fire embrace,
merging into one,
to enter the Palace of the Spirit."*

「When the breath is settled and inner observation attained,
with a single mind undivided,
both spirit and insight become wondrous.
In stillness, one often hears melodious sounds,
like a dream yet not a dream,
as if amid boundless void,
where winds and landscapes surpass the mundane dust.
Opulence and splendor outshine the human world—
palaces and gates, jade tiles gleaming with frost.
Feathers of jade and brocade, fragrant as clouds of incense,
when this moment arrives,
one ascends the Inner Court,
the yang spirit gathers and returns to the Upper Elixir Field,
refining into an immortal,
to merge with the Great Dao.
A single strike at the Great Gate—
golden light reveals the Dharma Body within the shadowy glow,
amidst flowers in bloom, the mundane form sits still.
Riding the void, one soars across flat plains,
ten thousand miles like stretching one’s arms.»

*The Transmission of the Dao Collection* says:
*"When clouds and thunder descend,
and smoke and flames ascend,
it may be as if the heavens rain strange blossoms,
auspicious winds and celestial qi arise from the palace courtyard.
Or like celestial maidens and jade-feathered cranes,
rainbow-winged phoenixes descending from the Azure Sky,
bearing golden platters of luminous dew and River Vehicle essence,
to present before the Sage.
This is the symbol of the Golden Elixir Returning to the Elixir Field—
the *Ji* (achievement) phase.
The Dragon and Tiger drag the River Vehicle through fire,
surging past the Three Passes,
each pass guarded by countless officials,
their numbers beyond reckoning.
Their armor and weapons strike fear in mortals—
first, the Dragon and Tiger clash yet fail to open it,
then great fire burns until the gate at last unfolds,
until the Kun Chamber cannot contain them,
and they reach the Heavenly Pool before ceasing.
Or like three cranes surging toward the sky,
or twin butterflies entering the Three Palaces,
or five-colored clouds bearing a child in scarlet robes,
passing through the Heavenly Gate,
or golden chariots and jade litters conveying the Sage,
soaring past the Three Realms—
these are the symbols of the *Arm’s Gold Ascending* and the Great River Vehicle.
When one official delivers the decree,
the Nine Continents harmonize in unison,
cycling endlessly, their operations ceasing not—
like wandering the Five Sacred Mountains,
or drifting across the Five Lakes,
or the Celestial Edict commanding the Five Emperors,
or the Sovereign’s mandate summoning the feudal lords—
these are the symbols of the Returning to the Elixir Field.*

*The Transmission of the Dao Collection* says:
*"From above descending below,
the Purple River Vehicle transports essence into the Heavenly Palace,
where wealth and honor abound—
who would not envy?
Coming and going in splendor,
luxury beyond mortal sight,
all present.
Those who follow the Dao
keep themselves pure and serene in daily life,
unbound, solitary, and long withdrawn from the world.
When their practice reaches fulfillment,
their joy knows no limit—
palaces of pearls and jade,
music and dance of celestial maidens,
rare delicacies and exotic feasts,
strange grasses and marvelous flowers,
scenery and breezes like painted visions.
If others do not awaken,
they may think it real—
that one has truly arrived at the Heavenly Palace,
not realizing the Inner Court’s own domain,
mistaking illusion for reality,
and clinging without escape.
Thus, they linger in the dim crossroads,
retain their form in this world,
and fail to transcend their substance to become immortals.

Before reaching the Heavenly Palace,
one remains in inner observation—
outer demons and inner ghosts,
stirred by intent, create false realms,
as if an army of fiends.
Driven mad, they plunge into error,
or lose themselves to heterodox paths,
even failing to become immortals.
For the Three Corpses and Seven Orifices
desire only the death of others,
while their own joy remains unfulfilled.
The Nine Vermin and Six Thieves
torment those who dwell in peace,
leaving no refuge for those who would escape.
Thus, they remain trapped in the world’s illusions,
unable to ascend."*

Zhu Yuanyou said:
*"When the first movement of Yang stirs,
urgently kindle fire to respond—
it must be a fierce boiling and rapid refining,
with the functions of inhalation, licking, and gathering,
forcing the golden elixir from the furnace flames.
Now that the upper opening is achieved,
seize this fiery force,
drive the River Chariot in reverse,
from the tail end against the current,
ascending to Kunlun’s Heavenly Valley Cavity—
like dragons battling tigers,
phoenix waves surging,
shaking heaven and earth.
After copulation,
a single point descends to the Yellow Court’s center.
From then on, apply the function of nurturing warmth—
like a dragon guarding a pearl,
like a hen brooding an egg,
silently returning the light,
neither forgetting nor aiding.
When the Mysterious Pearl takes form,
Taiyi contains the True Essence,
and naturally transforms to transcend."*

Zhu Yuanyou said:
*"When the Golden Elixir forms the embryo,
the pulse halts and the breath stops,
returning to the chaos of the undifferentiated.
This is the time of my body’s great death.
After long oblivion, rebirth awakens—
one attains the original face,
naturally pure and spotless,
with enlightened nature fully awakened,
the vast earth and sky
transformed into a crystal palace."*

Zhu Yuanyou said:
*"When the Divine Elixir Furnace is established,
guard it with true intent,
protecting it vigilantly—
not a moment may it depart.
If true intent strays from its place,
there may be the danger of confusion and loss."*

Zhu Yuanyou said:
*"The primordial ancestral *qi* is the sovereign,
the post-heavenal essence-*qi* the minister.
Once the furnace obtains the primordial *qi*,
it borrows the post-heavenal essence-*qi*
to nourish and encircle it."*

Yuanzi of the Governing Vessel said:
*"Form and spirit act without effort,
yet essence and *qi* naturally act of their own accord—
just as Heaven and Earth act without effort,
yet all things naturally transform and nurture."*

Master Lü’s *Golden Jade Scripture* says:
*"The dark dragon embraces the One,
the golden pearl radiates supreme light.
The white tiger contains the Three,
the purple snow nurtures the immortal’s bud."*

The *Golden Jade Scripture* says:
*"Nine layers of iron drums sound impartially,
a single golden bell rings upward.
Piercing the Heavenly Hall,
penetrating the Purple Bureau’s Furnace Mountain,
ascending to the Zhurong Peak,
the banks of the Jade Pool—
the *Samādhi* of Threefold Concentration.
A single breath pierces the Yellow Center,
the lead-pearl returns to the treasure vault."*

The *Chant of the True Words* says:
*"Always remain alert and lively."*

The *Chant of the True Words* says:
*"To form the sacred embryo,
first ascend to Perfect Awareness—
this is the essential instruction.
The art of regulation lies in ascent and descent.
The secret of ascent and descent lies in still observation.
Stillness is not absolute stillness—
within stillness, there is movement.
Movement is not true movement—
creation turns in cycles.
Observation is not fixed observation—
within observation, there is awareness.
Awareness is not true awareness—
the numinous light flickers indistinctly.
At this moment,
the furnace is empty yet the elixir is real,
water is firm while fire is yielding.
Each boiling, each refining,
each inhalation, each exhalation—
its essence aligns with Heaven and Earth’s mysterious transformation,
with the sun and moon’s revolutions,
with yin and yang’s purity and turbidity,
with the four seasons’ succession."*

The *Chant of the True Words* says:
*"Refining the elixir is like eating—
too hasty, it burns;
too slow, it rots.
Neither too hasty nor too slow,
then the flavor is complete.
If the elixir’s fire is too fierce,
lead flees and mercury scatters—
thus, it must be gentle, as if barely present.
If the fire is too slow,
the furnace grows cold—
thus, it must be ever-alert.
Neither too fierce nor too slow,
when the moment arrives,
all yin dissipates,
the yang spirit manifests."*

The *Chant of the True Words* says:
*"With a boundless heart,
reaching the sublime where the self is forgotten,
no self, no other—
what heaven, what earth?
Awakening to the empty *qi*,
within the indistinct chaos,
a single point of true yang—
it is me, yet not me;
it is void, yet not void.
Creation turns in cycles,
light and darkness alternate—
divided, it cannot be divided;
united, it cannot be united.
With the yang spirit’s void,
uniting with the Great Void’s void,
they blend seamlessly—
this is the perfection of form and spirit,
uniting with the Dao’s truth."*

The *Chant of the True Words* says:
*"Gentle, as if barely present—
use it without overdoing.
Ever-alert—
guard it without failure."*

The *Chant of the True Words* says:
*"Begin with non-action,
end with non-thought,
then Heaven clears above in serenity,
Earth steadies below in its place,
and only then do yin and yang blend to form the pearl,
collected within the deepest of orifices.
Tumbled, inverted,
dimly luminous—
a single furnace’s creation,
ten thousand measures of divine light."*

The *Chant of the True Words* says:
*"The millet-pearl contains all things,
the four seasons complete,
the eight winds stilled,
the Three Powers fulfilled."*

The *Chant of the True Words* says:
*"Gold’s essence and wood’s fluid clash in battle,
striking the nine-layered *tianluo* bell,
plucking the eight-wind lute—
the sun and moon emerge from the navel,
winds and clouds rise from the armpits,
round and radiant,
yet still a single Clear Void Cavern,
the primordial *hun*’s *qi*—the Supreme Ultimate.
Within it are heaven and earth,
are sun and moon.
Flying, creeping, moving, planting,
egg-born, wet-nurtured—
not a single thing is lacking.
When the numinous spark arrives,
all sounds resound together,
the One Principle manifests—
inexpressible."*

The *Chant of the True Words* says:
*"The *dou* and *gang* stars begin their revolution,
yin and yang invert as a result.
When the work is complete and the Dao achieved,
pure yang’s most potent *qi*
permeates the flesh and refines the bones,
the body’s law is gentle and harmonious,
swallowing all four seasons.
The Great Sun rests atop the head,
with no night.
Creation dwells within the body,
with no killing."*

The *"Chant of the True Words"* says:
*"The qi of the whole body circulates and ascends in cycles,
resonating with the **Great Heavenly Circuit**,
like the flood tide of the fifteenth night—
rising tumultuous and fierce,
penetrating the sinews and purging the marrow,
shattering the bones and joints.
Essential is calmness in action,
clarity in circumstance—
let others unleash winds and waves upon the river,
while my vessel follows the rudder’s turn."*

Zhang Sanfeng’s *"Essentials of the Golden Elixir"* states:
*"The Three Flowers converge at the crown,
the Five Qi bow toward the Primordial.
This is where yin is consumed and yang grows long,
where dross is refined and essence becomes pure.
The whole body is suffused with pure yang—
the old shell is shed, the bones renewed,
the five viscera regenerated,
the hundred limbs re-established.
When the liver is transformed,
its brilliance fills the eyes—
the pupils gleam like tiger’s lacquer.
When the heart is transformed,
its wisdom flows from the mouth—
blood crystallizes into white bones.
When the spleen is transformed,
the flesh solidifies like congealed fat,
the face blooms with powdered radiance.
When the lungs are transformed,
the nostrils scent celestial fragrance,
the complexion returns to that of a child.
When the kidneys are transformed,
the ears hear the music of the heavens,
the hair turns ashen-white with sudden clarity.
With such efficacy achieved,
the spirit naturally departs."*

Zhang Sanfeng in *The Rootless Tree* says:
*"The artisan’s skill is masterful, gripping the helm firm—
let the surging tides churn at the ocean’s depths.
Pass the Three Passes, pierce the Muddy Pill,
and soon the nine orifices of the body are all pierced through."*

Cao Wenyixian, the Immortal Maiden, says:
*"The Original Unity’s internal cultivation alone is true—
seeking breath externally is never complete."*

*The Golden Elixir Key Points* says:
*"Adjust the stepping-breath to be continuous and unbroken,
inhaling and exhaling in harmony—
the mind remains silent, inwardly still and outwardly clear,
as if present yet absent, the spirit condensed, the qi solidified."*

Chen Xiyi says:
*"Sudden—fire wheels seethe the earth’s meridians,
and the spirit bursts forth from the mountain’s peak."*

Qiu Changchun says:
*"The Golden Elixir surges upward, overturning the Heavenly Gang,
what fear of blocked bridges or barricaded passes?
With single-minded resolve, the spirit stirs not—
the six senses unmoved, guiding the circulation."*

*The Records of Daoist-Buddhist Fusion* says:
*"Once the Great Elixir elixir is obtained and the River Chariot is reversed,
entering the Godly Chamber,
if the divine light fails to illuminate,
the elixir loses its counterpart and dissipates swiftly.
Thus, the Original Spirit must serve as the elixir’s refuge,
and the elixir must refine the Original Spirit—
the two abide in inseparable stillness and luminosity."*

*The Records of Daoist-Buddhist Fusion* says:
*"After ingesting the Great Elixir,
the blockages at the Three Passes and Nine Orifices are all cleared.
Know that thereafter, the two *qi* will spontaneously generate,
naturally moving through the now-open pathways."*

*The Records of Daoist-Buddhist Fusion* says:
*"On the Ten-Month Pass and its bodily verifications,
Master Chongxu said:
‘When first entering *dhyāna*, if one steadfastly abides for three months,
the movement of the two *qi* is extremely subtle,
merely stirring at the navel’s void.
If one perseveres to four or five months,
the two *qi*, under the spirit’s stillness and luminosity,
cease their nourishing currents entirely,
all converging at the *dhyāna*-point.
The Original Spirit, nurtured by the two *qi*,
attains unobstructed Yang-Ming and realizes True Emptiness.
The two *qi* cease, the nourishing currents are cut—
only the still-luminous Original Spirit remains as the master of the fetal immortal.

If one guards further to six or seven months,
not only does the mind cease arising and passing,
but even slumber vanishes entirely.
If one guards to eight or nine months,
prolonged stillness and luminosity ensue,
and all meridians still.
If one guards to ten months,
the feet’s yang is pure, the spirit returns to Great Stillness—
thus, stillness generates wisdom,
and naturally arise the *divine eye*, *divine ear*,
*past-life recollection*, *mind-reading*,
and *spirit-realm penetration*.
Earlier, during the refining of essence,
there was already the *leakage-free penetration*;
now, the five later penetrations manifest.

The *divine eye* perceives celestial events,
the *divine ear* hears heavenly speech,
*past-life recollection* reveals karmic causes,
*mind-reading* foretells future matters.
Only *spirit-realm penetration* reveals the spirit’s operations—
if one fails to uphold the Heart-Sovereign,
the spirit-mind will usurp control,
delighting in one’s ability to cultivate and verify,
while the *delight-magic* has already infiltrated the heart.
Thus, one speaks eagerly of worldly calamities and fortunes,
of future schemes—
and disaster follows swiftly.

Only when wisdom is applied without attachment,
and recognition transforms into true insight,
can the fruit of the perfected fetal body be attained.
As the ancients said:
*‘Without interruption for thirty thousand breaths,*
*every step and sit must be clearly aligned with the Dao.’*
This illuminates that the Ten-Month Nurturing of the Fetal Body
lies solely in the unbroken, still-luminous practice.’"*

*The Records of Daoist-Buddhist Fusion* says:
*"If even a thread of drowsiness remains,
residual yin lingers.
If a single perturbing thought arises,
the spirit is not yet pure yang.
One must guard until drowsiness is utterly extinguished,
and all confusion vanishes—
only then is the fetal spirit fully ripe with pure yang.

*The Chaoyang Classic* says:
*‘Three hundred days of fire, ten months of fetal gestation.’*
At this inner stage, clarity dawns—
now, all demons emerge, luring one into other paths.
One must rely on habitual cultivation and virtuous deeds,
and the heavenly spirits will naturally aid.
After the elixir is sealed,
many phenomena arise—
all are the remnants of one’s lifelong habitual thoughts.
At this point, they all manifest.’"*

*The Scripture of the Soul’s Treasure* says:
*"What are called the hundred demons are the six senses, eight consciousnesses, the three souls and seven spirits, the three divisions and eight scenes, and the twenty-four deities within the body."*

*The True Scripture of the Cavernous Mysteries* says:
*"The celestial mechanism suddenly unfurls,
the great earth’s gold shines forth—
the primordial essence’s visage
now reveals its luminous form."*

*The True Scripture of the Cavernous Mysteries* also says:
*"The fleshly eye opens as the wisdom eye,
the common heart, once enlightened, becomes the true heart,
transforming the nature of transformation into the Buddha-nature,
and refining the consciousness-spirit into the primordial spirit."*

**Volume Eight: Detachment from the Fetal Body and Nourishment by Elixir**
*The Mirror of Alchemical Ingredients* says:
*"At the initial fetal formation, observe the native destiny.
At the final detachment from the fetal body, observe the four cardinal directions."*

Master Ziyang said:
*"When the seasonal rhythms have fully turned, the fetal body detaches and the spirit transmutes."*

Old Master Shixian declared:
*"When the elixir ripens, no dragon and tiger remain,
the fire ends, and mercury and lead rest.
Once the fetal body is detached and the spirit transmutes,
one becomes a Celestial Clarity Immortal."*

Ancestor Zhengyang said:
*"The child is young and not yet grown,
it must rely on the nurturing grace of the Mother of the Earth."*

Ancestor Chunyang said:
*"Nine years of fire’s refinement pass directly,
then suddenly, the heavenly gate at the crown bursts open.
The True Person manifests with great magical powers—
from this point, one may be congratulated as a Heavenly Immortal."*

At this time, the *Zhāoyáng Jīng* states:
*"Tend to the infant carefully—whether ten steps, a hundred steps, a thousand, or ten thousand—gradually emerging. Should one be reckless, it will not endure wind and snow. Through long practice until maturity, one penetrates metal and pierces stone, walks on fire and treads water, reaches heaven and traverses earth, comes and goes without hindrance, hidden yet manifest. As one wills, so it is done—whether one or a hundred, a thousand million incarnations."*

The *Huángtíng Jīng* asks:
*"Gazing upon the child seated in stillness,
Who is this child within my own body?"*

The *Cāntóng Qì* commands:
*"Diligently practice without ceasing, day and night.
After three years of hidden nourishment, lightness and boundless movement follow.
Striding through fire, unscathed;
Entering water, unsoaked.
Presence and absence at will—
Endless joy, no sorrow."*

The *Tiānxiān Zhènglǐ* explains:
*"Adjusting the spirit to emerge from the shell as an external body,
From the Upper Field, the mind projects outward;
From the external body, the mind returns to the Upper Field.
With each ebb and flow, the emergence grows refined,
The nourishment deepens.
Thus, after three years of divine suckling,
The spirit becomes complete—
Capable of myriad transformations,
Ascending to heaven and descending to earth,
Crossing seas and moving mountains,
Alleviating drought and flood,
Saving the world and its people,
Destroying evil and banishing harm.
Whatever is wrought is the work of a single spirit.
Spirit transforms, spirit manifests—
This is the Dao of the Immortal."*

The *Tiānxiān Zhènglǐ* further declares:
*"When cultivation reaches the stage of spirit-emergence,
Death and birth are forever transcended.
Calamities and demons hold no sway.
At first, when the spirit emerges—
If it steps out once and returns,
Or twice and returns—
Whether ten steps or a hundred,
One must tend to it with care.
Only then may divine nourishment mature the spirit
Until full ripeness—
Three years hence."*

The *Tiānxiān Zhènglǐ* warns:
*"Adjusting the spirit to emerge from the shell is a critical juncture,
Fraught with great peril.
At first, let it emerge and swiftly return,
Not lingering long,
Nor perceiving distant realms.
With prolonged practice, the emergence may endure,
And distant sights and sounds may be glimpsed before return.
For if it rushes outward too swiftly,
It may lose its true nature."*

Master Zhāng Sānfēng’s *Jīndān Jiéyào* states:
*"Once the infant emerges,
Continuously adjust the spirit,
Endlessly emerging from the shell.
At first, return immediately—
Guard the vital form closely.
From near to far,
The spirit’s heat turns white.
In an instant, a thousand miles traverse.
The elixir furnace and vessel are abandoned—
What further use is there for technique?"*

*The *Chàngdào Zhēnyán* says:*

*"When the Yang-spirit sheds its form,
There is a radiance emanating from the navel wheel,
And a fragrance issuing from nose and mouth—
These are the omens of shedding the form.

After shedding, golden light radiates in all directions,
Hairs and pores glow crystal-clear,
Like the sun rising over the sea,
Or a pearl first glimpsed in the depths,
While the scent pervades the room.

A single thunderous crack—
Golden fire mingles, and the Yang-spirit
Already rests within the *níwán* [cinnabar field, 丹丸].

Once it has emerged,
All depends on one’s daily cultivation.
That is why I first spoke of refining the heart—
This is precisely its purpose.

If the heart is cultivated to be empty and luminous,
Then the Yang-spirit is pure *xiāntiān língqì* [preheaven essence-qi],
Originally devoid of thought or action,
Unstained by encounters, unmoved by sights,
Its retreat and extension under my command,
Its coming and going effortless as ever.
With its entry into the *níwán*,
The body feels as if aflame,
Golden light again streams from the pores,
And the fragrance fills the air once more.

In an instant,
It returns to the *Huángtíng* [Yellow Court],
As though nothing had happened—
Unknowing, unaware—
This is the true realm."*

*The *Chàngdào Zhēnyán* further states:*
*"The Yang-spirit, after shedding its form,
Returns to the Void—
Purple *qì* [vital energy] shimmering within light,
Something yet not a thing,
Form yet not a form,
Symbol-less yet the ultimate symbol,
Soundless yet the source of sound."*

*The *Chàngdào Zhēnyán* declares:*
*"The true Yang-spirit,
After piercing the crown,
Dwells in the *Tàixū* [Great Emptiness],
At ease, unbound—
In an instant, it soars ten thousand miles.

Above, it can caress the sun and moon,
Treading lightly on clouds and mists.
Below, it can roam the islands and seas,
Gazing upon scenic marvels."*

「Thousands of transformations, a will unbound—
All as the heart desires.»

*The *Yánfó Hézōng Yùlù* [Records of the Union of Immortals and Buddhas] states:*
*"When the spirit departs, a scene unfolds—
One must refine the cultivation of nurturing.
Suddenly, within stillness, the Six Radiant [outflows] scatter in the void,
This is the vision of the departing spirit.
Then, one must adjust the spirit to exit the shell,
Stepping beyond the Celestial Gate before withdrawing once more.
To depart is to transcend the Great Emptiness,
To withdraw is to return to the Upper Fields as the place of nurturing.
Know this: the time spent departing and returning is brief,
While the time for nurturing is long.
Departure should not linger—
Even a single step taken must be withdrawn immediately.
With time, one may withdraw after a *lǐ* [~500m], or after many steps,
Or after a hundred *lǐ*, or a thousand *lǐ*—
Yet this must be done gradually, not abruptly.
For if so, the infant-spirit, still young and small,
Might be lost and fail to return.
Or a Heavenly Demon may come to test,
Disrupting the mind—thus one must be cautious in both departure and return,
Only then preserving the entirety of the Void
Amidst the comings and goings,
Lest the great nourishment of the milk-beast [i.e., the primal essence] be lost.

But for those with the seeds of Immortals and Buddhas,
When the initial return-to-the-Void is pure,
The Spirit Platform [mind] is serene and undefiled,
No dust clings—where would dust come from?
This is beyond the reach of ordinary mortals.
Thus, cultivators must prioritize the initial return-to-the-Void as their urgent task."*

*The *Dòngxuán Jīng* [Scripture of the Mystic Cavern] states:*
*"Depart, and roam the world;
Return, and dwell hidden within the *níwán* [mud-ball, i.e., the lower *dantian*].*
Chapter Nine: *Yìngshì Lìgōng* [Responding to the World and Establishing Merit]"

「The Master of the Clouds said: *"To have power without practice is like lacking feet; to have practice without power is to have incomplete vision. When both power and practice are complete, vision is fulfilled. Who says one without power cannot become an Immortal?"*

The Master Lü said: *"The path to Penglai Mountain relies on fulfilling three thousand deeds of virtue, then walking alone in the clouds."*

The Master of Shangyang said: *"When the elixir is refined and the fetal embryo is complete, a child of the Way is born as a True Person, and one must then establish deeds and accumulate merit. Some remain in the world to aid others and guide humanity, like Anqi Sheng and Lan Caihe. Some enter officialdom, rectify the times, and govern affairs, like Dongfang Shuo and Dou Lingjun. As for the Five Ancestors and Seven True Ones, they show boundless compassion and aid others; the Ancestors Zhang, Ge, Xu, Fu, and Qiu ascend upon imperial decree to save the world and assist the Way. If one seeks further advancement, then relocating the embryo and changing the elixir furnace is no great difficulty."*

The Master of Shangyang further said: *"After attaining the Dao, the elixir chamber and its vessels are abandoned. If one does not abandon them, the mind and environment may be defiled, risking dishonor."*

*"The Celestial Master Zhang Daoling, after refining his elixir, told his disciple Wang Chang: 'Taking the elixir should allow one to ascend to the heavens. Yet I have no great deeds to offer the state. How dare I take it so soon? You should first act for the nation’s benefit, removing its calamities, and then take the elixir. Only then can I serve the Three Realms without shame.'"*"

When Sun Zhenren asked the two elders of Yi and Luo: *"I have cultivated the heart for fifty years, yet the heavens do not recognize my efforts. Why?"*
They replied: *"Unless you benefit living beings, how can you ascend to heaven?"*
Thereupon, he returned to Qingcheng Mountain, compiled the *Qianjin Fang* [Thousand-Gold Prescriptions] in thirty volumes, and in broad daylight ascended to the heavens.

*The *Xianchuan Shiyi* [Lost Records of Immortals] states: *"Though practitioners may hide in countless ways, they have not escaped the cycle of death. They must dwell in the subtle realm with their hearts, focus on refining the elixir, establish deeds to aid the outer world, and cultivate their essence to preserve the inner. Only when inner and outer are harmonized can one attain the Dao and achieve lasting existence."*

*The *Qiangyang Jing* [Scripture of the Firewood Grove] says: *"Complete three thousand deeds of virtue, then aid the world and rescue the poor."*

Zhang Sanfeng’s *Jindan Jieyao* [Essentials of the Golden Elixir] states: *"With three thousand deeds fulfilled, the yang spirit transforms and becomes spiritually enlightened, wandering freely through the Eight Extremes without obstruction. It is especially fitting to accumulate deeds and virtue, awaiting the celestial decree to descend, then ascending in broad daylight to the heavens. One attains the highest rank of Heavenly Immortals, equal in magnitude to the Heavenly and Earthly Dao, and radiant as the sun and moon."*

*The *Wuzhen* [Awakening to Reality] says: *"When virtue and power reach eight hundred, and the accumulated deeds of darkness fulfill three thousand, then the balance of self and others, along with the resolution of grievances, aligns with the original vow of Immortals."*

The *Shigan Jidan Zhenghua Ge* [Song of the Stone Chamber Proving the Elixir and Attaining the Dao] states:
*"Hidden in the mortal realm,
Accumulating deeds of virtue in secret.
All who cling to worldly splendor
Shall never reach the Court of Jade Purity.
To the sick, I give medicine;
To the poor, I bestow gold and silver.
I pass on the elixir scriptures to scholars,
And reveal the oral keys to the Way.
When deeds and virtue are complete,
The celestial decree arrives at the Great Polarity."*

*The *Dòngxuán Zhēn Jīng* [Scripture of the Mystic Cavern’s True Essence] says:
*"Conceal your light and withdraw your traces,
Blend with the common and mingle with dust.
Roam within the Three Realms,
Preserve the heart to awaken the world.
Drive away malevolence and support the true Dao,
Manifest forms to enlighten the stubborn and ignorant.
Dispense medicine to cure sickness and suffering,
Scatter wealth to rescue the orphaned and indigent.
Some resolve injustices and punish the wronged,
Others alleviate difficulties and dispel chaos.
They admonish the unfilial and disobedient,
And guide the unrighteous and unvirtuous.
Wherever you go, propagate the great Dao,
Pointing out the path to those lost in delusion according to their karmic inclinations.
Widely bestow the *fǎrǔ* [law’s nourishment],
And guide beings to the Way,
To repay the Master’s virtue,
And to honor the恩 of one’s kin."*"

Chapter Ten: *Tiānyuán Guījí* [Heavenly Origin, Return to the Extremes]」

The **Shàng Yáng Zi** said:
*"When the prenatal essence is fully refined,
And one has already become a True Person,
Then one ascends to the Upper Elixir Field,
Realigns Heaven and Earth,
Renews Yin and Yang,
And gives birth to son and grandson—
A myriad, countless transformations."*

The *Jīn Dān Sìbǎi Zì* states:
*"In one year, a child is born,
Each child able to ride a crane."*

The **Ní Wán Zǔ** declared:
*"In one year, a child is born from the prenatal essence—
Son begets grandson, and grandson branches forth,
Only then is one a true Great Man."*

The **Dān Yáng Zǔ** proclaimed:
*"The spirit fills the boundless void,
Yet meets no obstruction—
Thus, heaven sometimes collapses,
Earth sometimes sinks,
Mountains sometimes crumble,
Seas sometimes dry up.
All formed things eventually decay,
But the Daoist alone remains unshaken through countless eons.
With accumulated virtue, one ascends to the Upper Pure in broad daylight."*

The *Zhuī Yáng Jīng* says:
*"When the second stage of cultivation is complete,
One rescues the world and uplifts the poor.
Refining the eyes to forge the spirit elixir—
The great medicine of perfection—
Form and spirit both attain marvelous purity,
Ascending in daylight,
Whole households lifted to celestial halls.
Yet this depends on the depth of one’s virtue.
If one does not take the spirit elixir,
Only the yang spirit surges upward,
Gazing back at the old corpse—
A heap of dung.
But if one cultivates the great elixir,
The golden pill enters the mouth,
And in daylight, one takes flight—
The universe then shares in its harmony."*

The **Lóng Méi Zi** spoke:
*"After nine years of facing the wall,
The luminous platform is clear,
The sea of awakening is bright,
Form and spirit both attain marvelous purity,
And merge with the True Dao.
Then, nature and life blend as one,
The boundless void becomes the self.
With virtue accumulated to three thousand,
And deeds meriting eight hundred,
One plays among mortals,
Lying dormant, awaiting the moment.
When the Heavenly Scriptures summon,
The body flies to the Golden Gate,
Returning to the Celestial Court—
What worldly wealth can compare?
This is the time when a Great Man fulfills his destiny and achieves renown."*

The *Cāntóng Qì* states:
*"When the Dao is perfected and virtue attained,
One lies dormant, awaiting the moment.
The Great Unity then summons,
And one relocates to the Central Continent.
With virtue complete, one ascends,
Receiving the talismans and scriptures.
The elixir’s efficacy is manifest."*

*"The *Chàngdào Zhēnyán* states:
'To wander beyond the Six Unities in famed mountains,
And observe the winds and *qi* of the eight directions, unmatched.
To pluck the *qin* in the groves of *qí* trees and jade plants,
And cultivate medicines in the halls of jade and fields of *zhī* herbs.
To assist the Celestial Sovereign in the realm of True Dao’s marvelous manifestation,
And hold the pivotal mechanisms in the palace of the Boundless and Supreme Ultimate.
Each attending to their duties without toil,
Each acting in their appointed ways without disorder.
The vastness of Heaven and Earth,
Like fingers upon the palm—near at hand,
What joy could surpass this?'

*The *Chàngdào Zhēnyán* further declares:
'The Dao’s marvel is natural,
The true realm is free and unbound,
Forever free from greed and attachment.'

*The *Chàngdào Zhēnyán* continues:
'Refining a single spark of original spirit,
Like moonlight rippling on water.
Spanning Heaven and Earth,
Permeating the *qiánkūn* [cosmic framework],
All compared to a cluster of violet radiance and golden light—
Ascending to the Three Pure Ones,
Descending through the Six Paths.
One will soon behold the Primordial Celestial Venerable,
And the Ancient Buddha *Pílú Zhēnà*,
Joyfully meeting them,
Shaking hands in fellowship,
After long separation,
Lamenting the delay of this reunion.'

Zhang Sanfeng in *The Essentials of Golden Elixir* says:
'To attain the Heavenly Immortal,
One must face the wall in seclusion.
Choose renowned mountains and blessed lands,
Ancient sites and sacred altars,
Where *qi* gathers and winds are stored,
Build a dwelling beside the clouds,
Backed by shade, facing the sun,
With a dragon’s head suspended like a gem-mirror before you,
And a sacred incense burner standing like a divine blade behind.
With such a supreme setting,
No calamity nor flood can disrupt—
The foundation is secure.
At first, one faces the wall,
Sitting motionless to nurture the spirit,
Emulating the emptied mind guarding the One,
Like a dragon nurturing the pearl beneath its chin,
Or a bird cradling its egg in the nest.
When form and spirit both attain marvelous purity,
And merge with the True Dao,
One enters water and fire without drowning or burning,
And walks with the sun and moon without trace or shadow.'

Cao Wenyixian initially said:
'Nine years of fulfilled labor, the fire’s readiness complete,
Responding to all things without thought—spirit transforms swiftly.'

Shaozi in *Poems of Tranquil Joy* states:
'Only after returning to the banks of the Great,
Do I truly believe a Great Man has been born.'

Zhang Ziyang in the *Preface to the Treatise on Awakening to the True* says:
'To reach this honored title in the Immortal Registers,
And the designation of True Person—
This is the time when a Great Man fulfills his destiny and achieves renown.'

*The *Records of the Unified Dao of Immortals and Buddhas* declare:
'The spirit does not manifest itself;
It returns to the Boundless Ultimate.
The body attains the Void—
Only thus does one perfect their enduring nature.
Heart and *dharma* transform together,
Law is forgotten as one.
Stillness without object,
Illumination without focus.
The Buddha said:
*"To verify the body of the Void,
One must demonstrate the law of the Void.
When the Void is realized,
There is neither ‘this’ nor ‘that’ law."*
The *Chàngdào Zhēnyán* proclaims:
'At this moment, form and spirit both attain marvelous purity,
Violet light and mysterious *qi* fill the heavens and earth.
When manifest, it becomes the sun and moon;
When sharp, it becomes thunder and lightning;
When stirring, it becomes wind;
When nourishing, it becomes rain.
Seeking voices to relieve suffering—
Without sensation, all is communicated.
Holding the pivotal mechanisms of Great Transformation,
One becomes parent to all beings.'

*The *Authentic Scripture of the Cavern of the Mystic Dao* states:
'Entering metal and stone without hindrance or obstruction,
Entering water and fire without drowning or burning.
In concealment, one walks the green mountains without trace or shadow;
In revelation, one fills the *dharma*-realm with myriad forms.
Dispersed, one becomes *qi*;
Gathered, one becomes form.
When form and spirit both attain marvelous purity,
And merge with the True Dao—
A perfect being between Heaven and Earth.
With virtue complete and deeds fulfilled,
Imperial decrees welcome one as guest.
Riding the *zhuànluán* [heavenly dragon] and straddling the crane,
One pays homage to the Celestial Court.
The Nine Mystic and Seven Ancestral lineages,
All attain transcendence—
This time, truly an Immortal,
This time, great renown achieved.
Let the ages pass,
I alone endure forever.

The True Light of the *Dharma*-realm,
Roams freely at will,
Expanding and transforming—
None can fathom its essence.
Revealing the great *dharma* form,
Emitting boundless radiance—
Hundreds, thousands, tens of millions of forms,
Fill the Void-realm entirely.'"

chunks.original_text: 济一子金溪傅金铨汇辑 集阳子定远萧康理校订　贞阳子临川李拱辰校订 来阳子定远凌光凌校字　宗阳子定远唐寿林校刊 序 余昔谓金简玉书、火龙水虎、至真之文心在诸天洞府、名山石室，数合之而遇之。 岂知天机不书竹帛，至道存于人间。 又谓金液玉液、真阴真阳、至妙之药必其潜天而天，潜地而地，不可思议，难于影响。 岂知不在渺远，即在眼前。 昔者始皇东游泰山，使童男、童女入海求不死之药，岂知此药不在海而在山。 汉武作露盘霄掌，餐沆隆金浆，岂知此浆不在天而在地。 所谓“遍地均开不谢花”，又曰“遍地开时隔爱河”，斯可证矣。 自太上授受以来，道脉不绝，责重于人。 心心相印，口口相传。 无少差谬，万古一贯。 此其奇也。 丹经秘密，假像立言。 迷之则阴阳判绝，悟之则水乳相融。 道固因书而理明，法必以言为切诀。 一经指破，始觉丹经万卷，总是陈言； 砂汞、铅银，都成色相。 其理至微，其事甚简。 如僧繇画龙，点睛飞去。 苟未经师指，尚是壁间之龙，无由观其神化。 乃知世间谈玄说妙，无异隔纸观灯，摘叶寻技，尽是剔窗窥月。 令将师边所得，印之简编，若《参同》、《悟真》及古圣仙经所留丹决、与夫诸家注流，一一证之。 择其至显至要之言，汇为一帙，秘之箧笥。 真正至道，至简至易。 易简而天下之理得矣，实乃一贯真机，不堪授受，聊以自娱，非欲求正于人也。 是为序。 时嘉庆十八年岁次癸酉除夕书于朝阳山之为本堂，济一子金溪傅金铨撰 发凡 一、扈言十万，如泛沧海。

Here is the translation:

---

**Preface**

Long ago, I held that the golden tablets and jade scrolls, the Fire Dragon and Water Tiger—texts of utmost truth—resided in celestial grotto-heavens and the stone chambers of sacred mountains, to be encountered only when fate aligned. Little did I know that the celestial mechanism is not inscribed on bamboo or silk, and the supreme Dao abides among men.

I once believed that the golden elixir and jade essence, true yin and true yang, the most wondrous medicine, must conceal themselves in heaven as heaven and in earth as earth, beyond conception, elusive as shadows and echoes. Little did I know that they lie not in distant realms but right before one’s eyes.

When the First Emperor of Qin journeyed east to Mount Tai, he sent boys and girls into the sea in search of the elixir of immortality—unaware that the medicine was not in the sea but in the mountains. Emperor Wu of Han erected dew basins and celestial palms, consuming the ethereal *hanglong* and golden nectar—unaware that the nectar was not in the heavens but upon the earth. As the saying goes, *“Flowers bloom everywhere, never withering,”* and again, *“When they bloom across the land, the River of Love is crossed.”* This is proof enough.

Since the Most High bestowed the transmission, the lineage of the Dao has never been severed, and its burden rests upon humanity. Heart transmits to heart, mouth to mouth. Without the slightest deviation, it has remained one and the same through ten thousand ages. Herein lies its marvel.

The alchemical classics are veiled in secrecy, their teachings couched in metaphors. Misunderstood, yin and yang become sundered; comprehended, water and milk merge as one. The Dao is made clear through texts, and methods are conveyed through spoken instructions. Once the key is revealed, one realizes that the myriad volumes of alchemical scriptures are but repetitions of old words, and cinnabar, mercury, lead, and silver are mere appearances.

Its principle is most subtle; its practice, most simple. Like the dragon painted by Zhang Sengyou, it takes but a touch to the eyes for it to take flight. Without a master’s guidance, it remains a dragon upon the wall, its divine transformations unseen. Thus, those who discourse on the profound and expound on the wondrous in this world differ little from gazing at a lamp through paper or plucking leaves in search of branches—all are but glimpses of the moon through a lattice.

Now, I have committed to these pages what I received from my teacher, comparing it with the *Zhoutong* and *Wuzhen* scriptures, the alchemical formulas left by ancient sages and immortals, and the commentaries of various schools. Selecting the most luminous and essential passages, I have compiled them into a single volume, treasuring it in my chest. The true and supreme Dao is utterly simple and effortless. Through simplicity, the principles of heaven and earth are attained—this is the unbroken thread of truth, not to be lightly transmitted. I record it here for my own delight, not to seek validation from others.

Written on New Year’s Eve of the *guiyou* year of the Jiaqing reign (1813) at the *Weiben* Hall of Chaoyang Mountain.

**By Ji Yi Zi, Fu Jinquan of Jinxī**

---

**General Principles**

1. A hundred thousand words are like drifting upon the vast sea.

chunks.original_text: 南针之指，亦茫乎无际矣。 兹将真机要语，分门逐类显而出之，其中调鼎、采药、行符、止火、开关、服食、胎息、出神、黄庭内景、黄庭外景，……无不俱备。 读者其细心玩索，融会天君，久之自然能贯注。 二、是书博采群经，旁搜远讨。 摘句编言，如披云见日，使人易悟。 始于有作，不死执清净为修行。 种德为先，不堕入三峰为学道。 万卷丹经，千秋绝业。 言言秘范，字字珠玑，后之学人，得睹如是章句，不必远睇《道藏》，穷览仙书，已证不二门之妙矣。 三、白紫清曰：“只一言贯串万卷丹经，然则万卷只是一卷，万言只是一言。 ”又曰：“一言半句妙通玄，何用丹书千万篇。 ”噫！ 何从而得此一言半句乎？ 若未逢师且看待，诗中藏决好修持。 烛昏慧炬，渡海慈航，舍书奚以哉？ 四、性命双修，原属一贯。 采药行符，初无二理。 明者省之。 五、法、财、侣、地，缺一不可。 鼎炉、符火，始终一致。 不可不知。 六、工夫以筑基始，以乳哺终。 药熟火化，端拱无为。 此后乃炼拔宅之神丹，了真空之本性，与天无极矣。 卷一　　总论 吴筠《玄纲论道德章》曰：“道者虚无之系，造化之根，神明之本，天地之源。 其大无外，其微无内。 浩旷无端，杳冥无对。 至幽靡察，而大明垂光； 至静无心，而品物有方。 混漠无形，寂寞无声。 万象以之生，五音以之成。 生者有极，成者必亏，生生成成，古今不移。 此之谓道也。 “德者天地所禀，阴阳所资。 经以五行，纬以四时。 牧之以君，训之以师。 幽明动植，咸得其宜。 泽流无穷，群生不知谢其功； 惠加无极，百姓不知赖其力。 此之谓德也。 “然则通而生之谓之道，道因无名焉。 蓄而成之谓之德，德固无称焉。 尝试论之。 “太极一动而分阴阳，阴阳混蒸而生万有，正在天地之间，故气象变通，晦明有类。 阳明而正，其粹为真录。 阴晦而邪，其精为魔魅。 故禀阳灵而生者为睿哲，资阴味而育者为凶顽。 阳好生，故睿哲者必惠和。 阴好杀，故凶顽者必悻戾。 或善或否者，乃二气均合而生，中人也。 三者各有所禀，而教安施乎？ 教之所施，为中人耳。 何者？ 睿哲不教而自知，凶顽虽教而不移，此皆受阴阳之纯气也，亦犹火可灭，不可使之寒。 冰可消，不可使之热。 理固然也。 “夫生我者道，禀我者神，而寿夭异，意识纷驰，去留不由于己，何也？ “以性动为倩，情反于道，故为化机所运，不能自持也。 将超迹于存亡之域，栖心于自得之乡者，道可以为师，神可以为友。 “何谓其然乎？ 盖道与神无为而气自化，无虑而物自成。 人于品汇之中，出于生死之表，故君子黜嗜欲、堕聪明、视无色、听无声，恬淡纯粹，体和神清。 希夷忘形，乃合至精。 此所谓返我之宗，复与道同。 造化莫能移，鬼神莫能知，况于人乎？ 通于道者，虽翱翔宇宙之外，而心常宁； 虽休息毫厘之内，而气自运。 故心不宁，则无以同乎道； 气不适，则无以存乎形。 形存道同，天地之德也。 是以动而不知其动者，超乎动者也。 静而不知其静者，出乎静者也。 超乎动者，阳不可得而推。 出乎静者，阴不可得而移。 阴阳不能变，而况于万物乎？ 故不为物所诱者，谓之至静，至静能契于至虚。

The southern pointer’s indication is likewise boundless and without limit. Here, I have taken the essential and pivotal sayings, divided them by category, and made them manifest. Within these pages, the regulation of the cauldron, the gathering of the medicine, the circulation of talismans, the cessation of fire, the opening of barriers, the ingestion of elixirs, embryonic breathing, the projection of spirit, the *Inner Radiance of the Yellow Court*, the *Outer Radiance of the Yellow Court*—none are lacking. May the reader ponder them with care, merging them with the sovereign mind; in time, they will naturally become integrated.

Second, this book broadly gathers from the many scriptures, searching far and wide. Extracting phrases and compiling sayings is like parting the clouds to see the sun, making enlightenment easy to attain. It begins with effort, not clinging to stillness as the sole path of cultivation. Planting virtue comes first, lest one fall into the three peaks in the study of the Dao. Ten thousand volumes of alchemical classics, a legacy of a thousand autumns—every line is a secret model, every word a pearl. Later learners who encounter such passages need not gaze afar at the *Daoist Canon* or exhaustively peruse the books of immortals, for they have already realized the wonder of the *Gate of Non-Duality*.

Third, Bai Ziqing said: “A single word threads through ten thousand volumes of alchemical classics; thus, ten thousand volumes are but one volume, ten thousand words but one word.” He also said: “A word or half a phrase, wondrously penetrating the mystery—what need is there for alchemical books by the thousands?” Alas! How does one come by this word or half-phrase? If you have not yet met a teacher, wait and observe; the verses conceal the method—cultivate well. A torch of wisdom dispels darkness; a compassionate vessel ferries across the sea. Without books, how could this be?

Fourth, the dual cultivation of nature and life originally belongs to one continuous thread. Gathering the medicine and circulating talismans are not two separate principles. Let the discerning take heed.

Fifth, the four essentials—method, resources, companions, and place—none may be lacking. The cauldron and furnace, the talismans and fire, must remain consistent from beginning to end. This must not be overlooked.

Sixth, the work begins with laying the foundation and ends with nurturing the infant. When the medicine ripens and the fire transforms, one sits in effortless dignity. Thereafter, one refines the divine elixir that elevates the dwelling, completes the true emptiness of original nature, and becomes boundless as heaven. Thus begins *Scroll One: General Discourse*.

Wu Jun’s *Treatise on the Mysterious Principle: Chapter on Dao and Virtue* states:

“The Dao is the lineage of emptiness and nothingness, the root of creation and transformation, the origin of spirit and illumination, the source of heaven and earth. Its vastness has no outer limit; its subtlety has no inner boundary. Boundless and without end, darkly obscure and without counterpart. Profoundly hidden and beyond perception, yet its great luminosity sheds light; utterly still and without intent, yet the myriad things take form. Vast and formless, silent and soundless. The ten thousand images arise from it; the five tones are perfected through it. That which is born has its limit; that which is completed must decline. Birth after birth, completion after completion—this has never changed from ancient times to the present. This is called the Dao.

“Virtue is what heaven and earth receive, what yin and yang rely upon. It is ordered by the five phases and woven by the four seasons. Governed by the ruler, instructed by the teacher. The hidden and the manifest, the moving and the still—all find their proper place. Its blessings flow without end, yet living beings do not thank it for its merit; its kindness extends without limit, yet the hundred clans do not rely upon its power. This is called virtue.

“Thus, that which permeates and gives life is called the Dao, and the Dao remains nameless. That which accumulates and brings to fruition is called virtue, and virtue remains unnameable. Let us attempt to discuss this:

“The Supreme Ultimate moves and divides into yin and yang. Yin and yang intermingle and steam forth, giving birth to the ten thousand things. This occurs within heaven and earth, hence the transformations of qi and the patterns of phenomena, the alternation of darkness and light. Yang is luminous and upright; its purest essence is the true record. Yin is dark and perverse; its essence becomes demonic specters. Thus, those born endowed with the numinous yang are wise and sagacious; those nurtured by the dull yin are fierce and stubborn. Yang delights in life, so the wise and sagacious are kind and harmonious. Yin delights in killing, so the fierce and stubborn are harsh and cruel. Those who are sometimes good and sometimes not are born of the balanced union of the two qi—they are the middling people. These three types each receive their endowment—how can teaching be applied to them? Teaching is applied to the middling people. Why? The wise and sagacious know without being taught; the fierce and stubborn cannot be changed even if taught. Both receive the pure qi of yin and yang, just as fire can be extinguished but cannot be made cold, and ice can be melted but cannot be made hot. This is the inherent principle.

“That which gives me life is the Dao; that which endows me is spirit. Yet lifespans differ, and thoughts scatter—departure and abiding do not depend on oneself. Why is this? When nature stirs and becomes emotion, it turns against the Dao. Thus, one is moved by the mechanism of transformation and cannot maintain control. For those who would transcend the realm of existence and cessation, and dwell in the land of self-attainment, the Dao can be their teacher, and spirit their friend.

“What does this mean? The Dao and spirit are without action, yet qi transforms of itself; without thought, yet things are completed of themselves. Among the ranks of beings, one emerges beyond the realm of life and death. Thus, the noble person rejects desires, casts aside cleverness, sees no colors, hears no sounds, abides in tranquility and purity, embodying harmony and clarity of spirit. Forgetting the form in the subtle and the imperceptible, one unites with the utmost essence. This is called returning to one’s origin, reuniting with the Dao. Creation cannot alter it; ghosts and spirits cannot know it—how much less can people? One who is attuned to the Dao may soar beyond the cosmos, yet the mind remains at peace; may rest within the finest space, yet qi circulates of itself. Thus, if the mind is not at peace, one cannot unite with the Dao; if qi is not harmonious, one cannot preserve the form. When the form is preserved and the Dao is united, this is the virtue of heaven and earth. Therefore, one who moves yet does not know they are moving has transcended movement. One who is still yet does not know they are still has gone beyond stillness. One who has transcended movement cannot be pushed by yang. One who has gone beyond stillness cannot be shifted by yin. If yin and yang cannot alter it, how much less can the ten thousand things? Thus, one who is not enticed by things is called *ultimate stillness*; ultimate stillness can unite with *ultimate emptiness*.”

chunks.original_text: 虚极则明，明极则莹，莹极则彻，彻极则天地之广、万物之殷、不能逃方寸之鉴矣。 “夫道包亿万之数而不为大，贯秋毫之末而不为小。 先虚无而不为始，后天地而不为终。 升清阳而不为明，沦重阴而不为晦。 本无神也，虚极而神自生。 本无气也，神运而气自化。 气本无质，凝委而成形，形本无情，动用而亏性。 形成性动，去道弥远。 故溺于死生，迁于阴阳，不能自止，非道存而亡之也。 故道能自无而生有，岂不能使有同于无乎？ 有同于无，则有不灭矣。 “阴与阳并，而人乃生。 魂为阳神，魄为阴灵。 结胎运气，肖体辨形。 然势不俱全，则各返其本。 故阴胜则阳竭而死，阳胜则阴消而仙。 柔和、慈善、贞清者，阳也。 刚狠、嫉妒、淫浊者，阴也。 心淡而虚，则阳和袭。 意燥而欲，则阴气入。 明此二者，阳胜阴伏，长生之渐也。 道不欲有心，有心则真气不集。 不欲无心，无心则客邪来舍。 故我心不倾，则物无不正。 动念有着，则物无不邪。 邪正之来，在我而已。 故上学之士，怠于存念者，阴尸胜之也。 忻于勤纯者，阳神胜之也。 一怠一勤者，其战未决也。 次之者，在于克节励操，使精专无掇于斯。 须久于其事者，则尸消而神主，谓之阳胜。 阳胜者，道其邻乎。 “夫形动而心静，神凝而迹移者，无为也。 闲居而神扰，拱默而心驰者，有为也。 无为则理，有为则乱。 虽无为至易，非至明者不可考也。 夫天地昼亦无为，夜亦无为，无为则一，而理乱有殊。 何哉？ 昼无以为明，故众阳见而群阴伏。 夜无以为晦，故群阴行而众阳息。 是故主明而无为者，则忠良进，奸佞匿，而天下理。 主暗而有为者，则忠良隐，奸佞职，而天下乱。 故达者之无为以慧，蔽者之无为以昏。 慧则通乎道，昏则同乎物。 “上学之士，时有高与远寄，陶然于自得之乡，调其真仙可接，霄汉可升者，神之主也。 虽曰神主，犹恐阳和之气发泄，阴邪之气承袭耳。 可入静室夷心，抑制所起，静默专一，则神不散而阳灵全。 谨无恣其康乐之情，以致阴邪之来耳。 若有时躁竞烦悖者，乃形中诸魄，为阳灵之气所炼，阴尸积滞，将散扰于绛宫之真。 可入静室，存一握固，候神清意平，合于虚静，斯亦洗心之一法也。 “言勿过乎行，行勿愧乎心。 行之不已，则天地爱之，神明佑之。 凶横无由如，鬼神不能扰。 若言情而行浊，名洁而迹污，虽丑蔽于外，而心惭于内。 天地疾之，神明殛之，虽力强于道，不可致也。 故宁受人之毁，无招天之谴。 人毁犹可弭，天遣不可逭也。 “道之所至忌者，淫杀阴贼。 此诚易戒。 至于小小喜怒、是非、可否，人情之常，甚难侦也。 都不有纤芥之事，关乎方寸之中，虑静神闲，则邪气不能入。 我志不扰，则真人为俦。 好誉而增毁者，贤达之所未免。 然审己无善，而获誉者不祥。 省躬无疵，而获谤者何伤？ “阳之精曰魂与神，阴之精曰尸与魄。 神胜则为善，尸强则为恶。 制恶兴善则理，忘善纵恶则乱。 理久则尸灭而魄炼，乱久则神逝而魂消。 尸灭魄炼者，神与形合而为仙。 神逝魂消者，尸与魄同而为鬼。 自然之道也。 “夫目以采色为华，心以声名为贵，身好轻鲜之饰，口欲珍奇之味，耳贪美好之音，鼻悦芳香之气，此六者皆败德伤性，伐其灵光者也。
chunks.translated_text:
When emptiness reaches its utmost, clarity arises; when clarity reaches its utmost, luminosity emerges; when luminosity reaches its utmost, transparency prevails; when transparency reaches its utmost, the vastness of heaven and earth and the teeming of the ten thousand things cannot escape the mirror of a single square inch.

“The Dao encompasses countless numbers yet is not great; it penetrates the tip of an autumn hair yet is not small. It precedes emptiness and nothingness yet is not the beginning; it follows heaven and earth yet is not the end. It ascends with pure yang yet is not bright; it sinks into heavy yin yet is not dark. It is not inherently numinous, yet when emptiness reaches its utmost, numinosity arises of itself. It is not inherently qi, yet when the numinous moves, qi transforms of itself. Qi has no inherent substance, yet when it congeals and accumulates, form takes shape; form has no inherent nature, yet when it moves and is put to use, nature is diminished. When form takes shape and nature moves, one drifts ever farther from the Dao. Thus, one drowns in life and death, shifts with yin and yang, and cannot come to rest—this is not because the Dao exists and then perishes. If the Dao can generate being from non-being, how much more can it make being merge with non-being? When being merges with non-being, being does not perish.

“Yin and yang unite, and humans are born. The hun is the yang spirit; the po is the yin soul. They coalesce as an embryo, circulate qi, model the body, and distinguish form. Yet if their power is not complete, each returns to its origin. Thus, when yin prevails, yang is exhausted and one dies; when yang prevails, yin dissolves and one becomes an immortal. Gentleness, kindness, integrity, and purity are yang. Harshness, jealousy, lewdness, and turbidity are yin. When the mind is tranquil and empty, yang harmony pervades. When intention is restless and desirous, yin qi enters. Understanding these two, when yang prevails and yin is subdued, one begins the path to long life.

“The Dao does not desire a mind, for if there is a mind, true qi does not gather. Yet it does not desire the absence of mind, for if there is no mind, external perversities take residence. Thus, when my mind does not incline, nothing is not upright. When thoughts attach to things, nothing is not perverse. The coming of perversity or uprightness lies with me alone. Therefore, those of superior learning who are negligent in preserving mindfulness are overcome by the yin corpse. Those who delight in diligent purity are overcome by the yang spirit. Those who alternate between negligence and diligence remain in unresolved struggle. The next level lies in disciplining conduct and fortifying integrity, making essence single-minded and undistracted. Those who persevere in this will see the corpse dissolve and the spirit preside—this is called yang prevailing. When yang prevails, one draws near the Dao.

“When the body moves yet the mind is still, when the spirit is concentrated yet the traces shift—this is non-action. When one dwells in leisure yet the spirit is agitated, when one sits in silence yet the mind wanders—this is action. Non-action brings order; action brings chaos. Though non-action is supremely easy, only those of utmost clarity can fathom it. Heaven and earth engage in non-action by day and by night; in non-action they are one, yet order and chaos differ. Why? By day, non-action is not brightness, so the host of yang appears and the multitude of yin hides. By night, non-action is not darkness, so the multitude of yin moves and the host of yang rests. Thus, when the ruler is enlightened and practices non-action, loyal ministers advance, treacherous officials withdraw, and the world is ordered. When the ruler is benighted and engages in action, loyal ministers retreat, treacherous officials take office, and the world falls into chaos. Therefore, the wise practice non-action with wisdom, while the deluded practice non-action in confusion. Wisdom leads to union with the Dao; confusion leads to identification with things.

“Those of superior learning at times lodge their aspirations in the lofty and distant, dwelling contentedly in the realm of self-attainment, harmonizing with true immortals they might meet, ascending to the celestial rivers—they are governed by the spirit. Though they are governed by the spirit, they must still guard against the dissipation of yang harmony and the encroachment of yin perversities. They may enter a quiet chamber, pacify the mind, suppress arising thoughts, and abide in stillness and single-mindedness, so that the spirit does not scatter and yang numinosity remains whole. They must be careful not to indulge in feelings of ease and joy, lest yin perversities draw near. If at times they grow restless, competitive, or agitated, this is because the various po within the body are being refined by yang numinous qi, and the accumulated stagnation of the yin corpse is about to disperse and disturb the true within the Crimson Palace. They may enter a quiet chamber, maintain a firm grasp, await the spirit’s clarity and the mind’s calm, and unite with emptiness and stillness—this too is a method for cleansing the mind.

“Let speech not exceed conduct; let conduct not shame the mind. When conduct continues without cease, heaven and earth cherish it, and the divine luminaries protect it. Calamity and violence have no way to approach; ghosts and spirits cannot disturb. But if one’s speech is passionate yet conduct is turbid, if one’s reputation is pure yet one’s traces are defiled, though shame may be concealed externally, the mind feels remorse within. Heaven and earth detest it; the divine luminaries strike it down. Though one may strive mightily for the Dao, it cannot be attained. Thus, it is better to endure others’ slander than to incur heaven’s censure. Human slander may yet be dispelled, but heaven’s punishment cannot be evaded.

“What the Dao most abhors is lewdness, killing, and yin treachery—these are truly easy to avoid. As for minor likes and dislikes, right and wrong, approval and disapproval, the common emotions of humanity, these are exceedingly difficult to discern. Even the slightest matter, if it concerns the square inch of the mind, when thoughts are still and the spirit at ease, perverse qi cannot enter. When my will is undisturbed, the true person becomes my companion. Those who seek praise and resent slander are not exempt even among the worthy and enlightened. Yet if one examines oneself and finds no goodness yet receives praise, this is inauspicious. If one reflects on oneself and finds no fault yet is slandered, what harm is there?

“The essence of yang is the hun and the spirit; the essence of yin is the corpse and the po. When the spirit prevails, one does good; when the corpse is strong, one does evil. Restraining evil and promoting good brings order; forgetting good and indulging evil brings chaos. When order endures, the corpse perishes and the po is refined. When chaos endures, the spirit departs and the hun dissolves. When the corpse perishes and the po is refined, the spirit and form unite to become an immortal. When the spirit departs and the hun dissolves, the corpse and po merge to become a ghost. This is the natural Dao.

“The eyes delight in bright colors as their splendor; the mind values fame and reputation as its treasure. The body favors light and fine adornments; the mouth craves rare and exquisite flavors. The ears covet beautiful sounds; the nose delights in fragrant scents. These six all corrupt virtue, harm nature, and fell the numinous radiance.”

chunks.original_text: 故有之则宜远，无之不足求。 惟衣与食，人之所切也，亦务道者之一弊耳。 然能委心任运，未有不给其所用。 且天地之生禽兽也，犹覆之以羽毛，供之以虫粒，而况于人乎？ 必在忘其所趣，任其自然。 觉与阳合，寐与阴并。 觉多则魂强，寐久则魄壮。 魂强者生之徒，魄壮者死之徒。 若餐元和、彻滋味，使神清气爽，至于昼夜不寐者，善无以加焉。 人心久任之，则浩荡而忘返。 顿栖之，则超跃而无垠。 任之则蔽乎我性，栖之则劳乎元神，使致道者，奚方而静？ 盖性本至凝，物感而动。 习动兹久，胡能遽宁？ 既习动而播迁，可习静而恬晏。 故善习者，寂而有裕。 不善习者，烦而无功。 是以将躁而制之以宁，将邪而闲之以正，将求而抑之以舍，将浊而澄之以清。 优哉游哉，不欲不营。 行于是，止于是，造次于是，逍遥于是。 习此久者，则物冥于外，神鉴于内，不思静而自静矣。 古人云：‘积习生常’，其斯之谓欤？ “或问：古今学仙者多，得道者少，何也？ 答曰：常人学道者千，而知道者一。 知道者千，而志道者一。 志道者千，而专精者一。 专精者千，而勤久者一。 是以学者众而成者寡也。 “或曰：仙者人之所至美者也，死者人之所至恶者也，世之君子，罔有不知。 而从俗者至多，习仙者至少，何也？ 答曰：此有一理，一者所禀之气非高，则所希之志难广，故溺于近务，忘于远见，为声色所靡，嗜欲所昏。 仙道贵实，人道贵华，仙道、人情，直相反耳。 诸恶可戒，诸善可修，万行周圆，一身清洁，终身无效，不生退怠，抱道而亡，不亏志节。 大抵外修福行，内神精神，内外功深，则仙阶可进，洞天可游矣。 古今成道者，皆福慧相须。 慧为灯火，福为灯油。 火无油则不明，慧性无福则不住。 故达士宁损其身，不损其福。 世之人虽天姿明敏，学海汪洋。 若福行未加，则终不能探道元之妙。 古今得道圣贤，道通为一，福则有异。 外功大者，仙位之高。 外行卑者，阶居其下。 所以天上圣贤，恶行之未广，则重下人间，以偿畴昔。 人间浊恶难修而功疾，天上清高易处而功缓。 轩辕久居天上，因议大行，落在人间，先世为民，再世为臣，三世为君，济物利生，功成乃仙去耳。 至于冥府，亦类人间，寸地尺天，皆有所辖，凡为主者，悉是在世有功之人也。 “我之本心，空如以前本来之面目，果何物哉？ 所谓杳兮冥兮，恍兮惚兮，不可以知知，不可以识识。 强名曰道，强名曰神，强名曰性，强名曰命，心如此而已。 由是观之，岂不大哉？ 岂不贵哉？ 然轮回生死，而不能自己者，何也？ 盖一念萌动于内，六识流转于外。 不趋乎善，则超乎恶。 故有天堂、地狱因果之报。 六道轮回，无有出期，可不痛哉？ 可不悲哉？ 若夫达人则不然，故斋戒以神明其德，一真澄湛，万祸消除。 自兹以往，谨言语，节饮食，除垢止念，清心守一，虚无恬淡，寂寞无为，收视返听，和光同尘，瞥起是病，不续是药。 不怕念起，惟恐觉迟，譬如有发，朝朝思理，有身有心，胡不如是？ 一念才动者，妄也。 越古今而不坏者，常也。 真常不易，其惟大人乎？ ” 上阳子曰：“夫道也者，位天地、育万物曰道，揭日月、生五行曰道，多于恒河沙数曰道，孤则独无一侣曰道，直入鸿蒙而还归溟滓曰道，善集造化而顿超圣凡曰道，目下机境未兆而突尔通灵曰道，眼前生杀分明而无能逃避曰道，处卑污而大尊贵曰道，居幽暗而极高明曰道。

Thus, what one possesses should be kept at a distance, while what one lacks need not be sought. Only clothing and food—so vital to people—are also the greatest hindrances for those who pursue the Dao. Yet if one surrenders the heart to fate and lets things take their course, nothing will fail to provide what is needed. Even as Heaven and Earth bring forth birds and beasts, they cover them with feathers and supply them with insects and grains—how much more so for humans? The key lies in forgetting one’s aims and following nature’s course. When awake, one merges with yang; when asleep, one unites with yin. Too much waking strengthens the *hun*; too much sleep fortifies the *po*. Those with strong *hun* belong to the living; those with strong *po* belong to the dead. If one consumes primordial harmony and refines away flavors, keeping the spirit clear and qi refreshed, even to the point of remaining awake day and night—nothing surpasses this in goodness. Yet if the human heart indulges this for long, it becomes vast and forgets to return. If one abruptly halts it, the heart leaps beyond all bounds. Indulgence obscures one’s nature; restraint wearies the primordial spirit. How then can the seeker of the Dao attain stillness?

For nature is fundamentally most serene, yet stirred by external things. Once habituated to movement, how can it suddenly find peace? Having grown accustomed to movement and been carried away by it, one may instead cultivate stillness and attain tranquility. Thus, those who cultivate well find abundance in quietude; those who cultivate poorly grow troubled without result. Therefore, when agitation arises, restrain it with calm; when deviance arises, guard it with correctness; when seeking arises, suppress it with renunciation; when turbidity arises, clarify it with purity. Leisurely and carefree, without desire or scheming—acting thus, halting thus, even in haste, one remains thus, wandering freely. With long practice, external things grow dim while the inner spirit becomes clear. One does not think of stillness yet attains it naturally.

The ancients said, “Accumulated habits become nature.” Is this not what they meant?

Someone asked: “Many have sought immortality through the ages, yet few have attained the Dao. Why is this?”

The answer: “Of a thousand who study the Dao, only one truly understands it. Of a thousand who understand it, only one is devoted to it. Of a thousand devoted to it, only one is single-minded. Of a thousand single-minded, only one persists long enough. Thus, many study, but few succeed.”

Another asked: “Immortality is humanity’s highest beauty, and death its greatest horror—everyone knows this. Yet why do so many follow the common path, while so few cultivate immortality?”

The answer: “There is one reason: if one’s endowment of qi is not lofty, one’s aspirations cannot be vast. Thus, one drowns in immediate concerns, forgets far-reaching vision, is ensnared by sensual pleasures, and dulled by desires. The Dao of immortality values substance; the human path values splendor. The Dao of immortality and human nature are directly opposed. All evils can be abandoned; all virtues can be cultivated. With perfect conduct, a pure body, and lifelong effort—without slackening or despair—one may embrace the Dao even in death without compromising integrity.

Generally, one must cultivate blessings externally and refine the spirit internally. With deep merit in both, the steps to immortality may be ascended, and the grotto-heavens explored. Those who have attained the Dao through the ages all relied on the mutual support of blessings and wisdom. Wisdom is the lamp’s flame; blessings are the lamp’s oil. Without oil, the flame does not shine; without blessings, wisdom does not endure. Thus, the enlightened would sooner harm their bodies than diminish their blessings. Though one may be naturally brilliant and learned, without accumulated blessings, one cannot fathom the Dao’s profound mysteries.

The sages and immortals of past and present share the same Dao, though their blessings differ. Those with greater external merit ascend to higher immortal ranks; those with lesser merit occupy lower stations. Thus, celestial sages whose virtuous deeds were insufficient may be sent back to the human realm to repay past debts. The human world is turbid and difficult to cultivate, yet merit accrues swiftly; the celestial realms are pure and easy to inhabit, yet merit accumulates slowly. The Yellow Emperor dwelled long in the heavens but, for debating grand deeds, was cast down to the mortal world. In his first life, he was a commoner; in his second, a minister; in his third, a sovereign. Only after aiding beings and benefiting life did he complete his merit and ascend as an immortal.

Even the underworld resembles the human realm, with every inch of land and span of sky under governance. All who rule there were once people of merit in the world.

My original heart is empty, like the face it had before birth—what is it, truly? Vast and obscure, fleeting and indistinct, it cannot be known by knowing, nor grasped by grasping. Forced to name it, we call it the Dao, the spirit, the nature, the destiny—yet it is only the heart. Seen thus, is it not vast? Is it not noble? Yet why, though bound to the cycle of birth and death, can one not master oneself? Because a single thought stirs within, and the six senses wander without. If one does not turn toward goodness, one drifts toward evil. Thus, there are the karmic retributions of heaven and hell, the six paths of rebirth without end. Is this not agonizing? Is this not lamentable?

The enlightened, however, are not thus. Through fasting and abstinence, they illumine their virtue. With a single truth settled and clear, all misfortunes vanish. From then on, they guard their speech, moderate their diet, eliminate impurities, halt stray thoughts, purify the heart, and hold to unity. Emptiness, tranquility, stillness, non-action—withdrawing sight and returning hearing, harmonizing with the world, they see sudden thoughts as illness and non-continuation as medicine. They do not fear thoughts arising, only fear awakening too late. Just as one daily tends to one’s hair, why not tend to body and mind thus? A single thought arising is delusion; that which transcends past and present without decay is the eternal. Is not the true and constant the mark of the great person?”

Master Shangyang said: “The Dao—it is the position of Heaven and Earth, the nurturing of the myriad things; it is the raising of the sun and moon, the generation of the Five Phases; it is more numerous than the sands of the Ganges; solitary, it has no peer; it enters the primordial chaos and returns to the primordial depths; it gathers the workings of creation and instantly transcends the sacred and the mundane; in the unmanifested moment before signs arise, it suddenly attains numinous communion; in the clear distinction of life and death before the eyes, none can escape it; dwelling in lowliness and filth, it is supremely noble; abiding in darkness and obscurity, it is utterly luminous.”
